infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian

Class ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
      • infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian.ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelCalculatorCommon, ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculator, InfoMeasureCalculatorContinuous, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer, EmpiricalNullDistributionComputer

    public class ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian
extends ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo
implements AnalyticNullDistributionComputer

    Computes the differential conditional transfer entropy (TE) between two univariate double[] time-series of observations (implementing ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculator), assuming that the probability distribution function for these observations is a multivariate Gaussian distribution. TE was defined by Schreiber, conditional TE by Lizier et al., and Kaiser and Schreiber showed how to compute TE via the Gaussian assumption. This estimator is realised here by plugging in ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian as the calculator into the parent class ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.

    That is, this class implements a conditional TE calculator using model of Gaussian variables with linear interactions, making it equivalent (up to a multiplicative constant) to the (partial) Granger causality (see Barnett et al below).

    Usage is as per the paradigm outlined for ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculator, with:

    • The constructor step being a simple call to ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorGaussian().
    • ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.setProperty(String, String) allowing properties defined for both ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculator.setProperty(String, String) and ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian.setProperty(String, String) as outlined in ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.setProperty(String, String)).
    • The user can call setCovariance(double[][], int) instead of supplying observations via ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.setObservations(double[], double[], double[][]) or ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.addObservations(double[], double[], double[][]) etc.
    • Computed values are in nats, not bits!
    • Additional method computeSignificance() to compute null distribution analytically.

    References:

    • T. Schreiber, "Measuring information transfer", Physical Review Letters 85 (2) pp.461-464, 2000.
    • L. Barnett, A. B. Barrett, A. K. Seth, "Granger Causality and Transfer Entropy Are Equivalent for Gaussian Variables", Physical Review Letters 103 (23) 238701, 2009;
    • A. Kaiser, T. Schreiber, "Information transfer in continuous processes", Physica D, Vol. 166, No. 1-2., pp. 43-62 (2002).
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Local information transfer as a spatiotemporal filter for complex systems" Physical Review E 77, 026110, 2008.
    • J. T. Lizier, M. Prokopenko and A. Zomaya, "Information modification and particle collisions in distributed computation" Chaos 20, 3, 037109 (2010).
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
    See Also:
    Differential entropy for Gaussian random variables at Mathworld, Differential entropy for Gaussian random variables at Wikipedia, Multivariate normal distribution on Wikipedia, ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculator, ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian

    • Method Detail

      • setCovariance

        public void setCovariance(double[][] covariance,
                 int numObservations)
                   throws java.lang.Exception

        Set the joint covariance of the distribution for which we will compute the transfer entropy.

        Note that without setting any observations, you cannot later call ConditionalTransferEntropyCalculatorViaCondMutualInfo.computeLocalOfPreviousObservations(), and without providing the means of the variables, you cannot later call #computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][], double[][]).

        Parameters:
        covariance - joint covariance matrix of source, dest, dest history and conditional variables, considered together.
        numObservations - the number of observations that the covariance was determined from. This is used for later significance calculations
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for covariance matrix not matching the expected dimensions, being non-square, asymmetric or non-positive definite

      • computeSignificance

        public ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance()
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate an analytic distribution of what the conditional TE would look like, under a null hypothesis that our source and destination variables had no relation (in the context of the conditional value). This is performed without bootstrapping (which is done in #computeSignificance(int, int) and #computeSignificance(int, int[][])). The method is implemented using the corresponding method of the underlying ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below, and the other papers referenced in AnalyticNullDistributionComputer.computeSignificance() (in particular Geweke), for a description of how this is done for TE and conditional MI. Basically, the null distribution is a chi-square distribution.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
        Returns:
        ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution object which describes the proportion of TE scores from the null distribution which have higher or equal conditional MIs to our actual value.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian#computeSignificance()}, "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."
